articles.title: First Trimester: What to Expect
articles.summary: A complete guide to the first 12 weeks of pregnancy and the changes your body will experience.
articles.content:
The first trimester is an exciting and sometimes challenging time. Your baby is developing rapidly, going from a tiny cluster of cells to having all major organs formed.

**Weeks 1-4:**
Conception occurs and the fertilized egg implants in your uterus. You may not even know you're pregnant yet!

**Weeks 5-8:**
The heart begins to beat, and tiny limb buds appear. You might start experiencing morning sickness and fatigue.

**Weeks 9-12:**
Your baby is now called a fetus. Fingers and toes are forming, and you may hear the heartbeat at your prenatal visit.

**Common Symptoms:**
- Morning sickness (can happen any time of day)
- Extreme fatigue
- Breast tenderness
- Frequent urination
- Food aversions or cravings

**Tips:**
- Take prenatal vitamins with folic acid
- Stay hydrated
- Rest when you need to
- Avoid alcohol, smoking, and raw foods

articles.title: Second Trimester: The Golden Period
articles.summary: Many women find the second trimester the most enjoyable. Here's what happens during weeks 13-27.
articles.content:
Welcome to the second trimester! Many women call this the 'golden period' because morning sickness often eases and energy returns.

**Weeks 13-16:**
Your baby can make facial expressions and may start sucking their thumb. You might start showing!

**Weeks 17-20:**
You may feel the first flutters of movement (quickening). The anatomy scan happens around week 20.

**Weeks 21-27:**
Your baby can hear you! They're growing quickly and developing sleep patterns.

**Common Symptoms:**
- Increased energy
- Visible baby bump
- Baby movements
- Back pain may begin
- Skin changes (linea nigra, stretch marks)

**Tips:**
- Start sleeping on your side
- Stay active with gentle exercise
- Begin planning the nursery
- Sign up for prenatal classes

articles.title: Third Trimester: The Home Stretch
articles.summary: The final weeks of pregnancy bring excitement and preparation. Learn what to expect from week 28 onwards.
articles.content:
You're in the home stretch! The third trimester brings rapid growth and preparation for birth.

**Weeks 28-32:**
Your baby is gaining weight rapidly. Start counting kicks daily. Braxton Hicks contractions may begin.

**Weeks 33-36:**
The baby moves into head-down position. Pack your hospital bag and finalize your birth plan.

**Weeks 37-40:**
Your baby is full-term at 37 weeks. Watch for signs of labor and stay in touch with your healthcare provider.

**Common Symptoms:**
- Shortness of breath
- Frequent urination (again!)
- Trouble sleeping
- Braxton Hicks contractions
- Nesting instinct

**Tips:**
- Count kicks daily
- Prepare your birth plan
- Pack your hospital bag
- Rest and conserve energy
- Know the signs of labor

articles.title: Pregnancy Nutrition Essentials
articles.summary: What to eat for a healthy pregnancy and proper baby development.
articles.content:
Good nutrition during pregnancy is crucial for your health and your baby's development.

**Key Nutrients:**

**Folic Acid (400-800 mcg daily)**
Prevents neural tube defects. Found in leafy greens, fortified cereals, and supplements.

**Iron (27 mg daily)**
Supports increased blood volume. Found in lean meat, beans, and fortified cereals.

**Calcium (1000 mg daily)**
Builds baby's bones and teeth. Found in dairy, fortified plant milk, and leafy greens.

**Protein (75-100g daily)**
Supports baby's growth. Found in meat, fish, eggs, beans, and dairy.

**Omega-3 Fatty Acids**
Supports brain development. Found in fatty fish (salmon, sardines) and DHA supplements.

**Foods to Include:**
- Colorful fruits and vegetables
- Whole grains
- Lean proteins
- Low-fat dairy
- Healthy fats (avocado, nuts)

**Foods to Limit:**
- Caffeine (under 200mg/day)
- High-mercury fish
- Processed foods
- Added sugars

articles.title: Safe Exercises During Pregnancy
articles.summary: Stay active and healthy with these pregnancy-safe workout options.
articles.content:
Exercise during pregnancy offers many benefits including improved mood, better sleep, and easier labor.

**Benefits of Exercise:**
- Reduces back pain
- Improves sleep
- Reduces stress and anxiety
- Helps manage weight gain
- May shorten labor

**Safe Exercises:**

**Walking**
The perfect low-impact exercise. Aim for 30 minutes daily.

**Swimming**
Supports your weight and is gentle on joints. Great for all trimesters.

**Prenatal Yoga**
Improves flexibility and relaxation. Helps prepare for labor.

**Stationary Cycling**
Safe cardio without balance concerns.

**Strength Training**
Light weights with proper form. Avoid lying flat on your back after first trimester.

**Exercises to Avoid:**
- Contact sports
- Activities with fall risk
- Hot yoga or hot tubs
- Lying flat on back (after 1st trimester)
- High-altitude activities

**Warning Signs to Stop:**
- Dizziness or shortness of breath
- Chest pain
- Vaginal bleeding
- Contractions
- Fluid leaking

articles.title: Managing Common Pregnancy Symptoms
articles.summary: Practical tips for dealing with nausea, fatigue, back pain, and more.
articles.content:
Pregnancy brings many physical changes. Here's how to manage common discomforts.

**Morning Sickness**
- Eat small, frequent meals
- Try ginger tea or candies
- Avoid strong smells
- Eat crackers before getting up
- Stay hydrated

**Fatigue**
- Rest when you can
- Go to bed earlier
- Light exercise can help
- Eat iron-rich foods
- Accept help from others

**Back Pain**
- Wear supportive shoes
- Sleep with a pillow between legs
- Practice good posture
- Gentle stretching
- Prenatal massage

**Heartburn**
- Eat smaller meals
- Avoid spicy and fatty foods
- Don't lie down right after eating
- Sleep propped up
- Antacids (ask your doctor)

**Swelling**
- Elevate your feet
- Stay hydrated
- Avoid standing too long
- Wear comfortable shoes
- Reduce salt intake

**When to Call Your Doctor:**
- Severe headaches
- Vision changes
- Sudden severe swelling
- Decreased baby movement
- Signs of preterm labor

articles.title: Preparing for Labor and Delivery
articles.summary: Everything you need to know to feel ready for the big day.
articles.content:
As your due date approaches, preparing for labor can help you feel more confident.

**Signs of Labor:**
- Contractions that get stronger and closer together
- Water breaking
- Bloody show (mucus plug)
- Back pain that doesn't go away
- Feeling the baby "drop"

**When to Go to the Hospital:**
- Contractions 5 minutes apart for 1 hour
- Water breaks (note color and time)
- Decreased baby movement
- Heavy bleeding
- Severe headache or vision changes

**Pain Management Options:**

**Natural Methods:**
- Breathing techniques
- Movement and position changes
- Water (shower or tub)
- Massage
- Birthing ball

**Medical Options:**
- Epidural
- IV pain medication
- Nitrous oxide (laughing gas)

**Your Birth Plan:**
Consider your preferences for:
- Who you want present
- Pain management
- Monitoring preferences
- Cord clamping timing
- Skin-to-skin contact
- Feeding preferences

Remember: Plans may change based on how labor progresses. Stay flexible!

articles.title: Mental Health During Pregnancy
articles.summary: Taking care of your emotional wellbeing is just as important as physical health.
articles.content:
Pregnancy brings emotional changes along with physical ones. It's important to prioritize your mental health.

**Common Feelings:**
- Joy and excitement
- Anxiety about the future
- Mood swings
- Worry about baby's health
- Changes in relationships

**Self-Care Tips:**
- Rest when you need to
- Stay connected with loved ones
- Limit stressful situations
- Practice relaxation techniques
- Gentle exercise
- Get enough sleep

**Warning Signs to Watch:**
- Persistent sadness or hopelessness
- Severe anxiety
- Changes in appetite or sleep
- Difficulty bonding with baby
- Thoughts of harming yourself or baby

**Getting Help:**
If you're struggling, reach out to:
- Your healthcare provider
- A mental health professional
- Support groups
- Trusted friends and family

**Postpartum Planning:**
Start thinking now about:
- Your support system
- Help with household tasks
- Signs of postpartum depression
- Resources available to you

You're not alone. Many women experience emotional challenges during pregnancy.

articles.title: Baby's Amazing Development
articles.summary: Marvel at how your baby grows from a tiny cell to a full-term baby.
articles.content:
Your baby's development is truly remarkable. Here's what happens during these 40 weeks.

**First Trimester (Weeks 1-12):**
- Week 4: Heart begins forming
- Week 6: Brain and spinal cord develop
- Week 8: All major organs are present
- Week 10: Fingers and toes separate
- Week 12: Baby can make movements

**Second Trimester (Weeks 13-27):**
- Week 14: Baby can make facial expressions
- Week 18: Can hear sounds
- Week 20: Halfway there! Can determine sex
- Week 24: Lungs are developing
- Week 27: Eyes can open and close

**Third Trimester (Weeks 28-40):**
- Week 28: Can respond to light
- Week 32: Bones fully formed (but soft)
- Week 36: Brain developing rapidly
- Week 37: Considered full-term
- Week 40: Ready for birth!

**Size Milestones:**
- Week 8: Size of a raspberry
- Week 12: Size of a lime
- Week 20: Size of a banana
- Week 30: Size of a cabbage
- Week 40: Size of a watermelon

Every week brings new developments. Your baby is growing stronger every day!

articles.title: Preparing for Postpartum
articles.summary: What to expect after birth and how to prepare for the fourth trimester.
articles.content:
The postpartum period (also called the fourth trimester) brings big changes. Being prepared can help.

**Physical Recovery:**
- Vaginal soreness or C-section healing
- Uterus contracting back to size
- Postpartum bleeding (lochia)
- Breast engorgement
- Fatigue and sleep deprivation

**Emotional Changes:**
- Baby blues (first 2 weeks)
- Bonding with baby
- Adjusting to new role
- Relationship changes
- Possible postpartum depression

**Recovery Tips:**
- Rest when baby sleeps
- Accept help from others
- Stay hydrated
- Eat nutritious foods
- Gentle movement when ready

**What to Prepare:**
- Comfortable recovery items
- Nursing supplies if breastfeeding
- Freezer meals
- Help lined up
- Baby essentials

**Warning Signs:**
- Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad in an hour)
- Fever over 100.4Â°F
- Severe headache or vision changes
- Thoughts of harming yourself or baby
- Signs of infection

**When to Call Doctor:**
- Your 6-week checkup is important
- Call sooner if you have concerns
- Don't wait if you're struggling emotionally
